A highly loaded Ni@SiO2 core–shell catalyst for CO methanation Pandian Lakshmanan Min Sik Kim Eun Duck Park ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering and Department of Energy Systems Research, Ajou University, 206, World cup-ro, Yeongtong-Gu, Suwon 443-749, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering and Department of Energy Systems Research Ajou University 206, World cup-ro Yeongtong-Gu Suwon 443-749 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +82 31 219 1612. Graphical abstract CO + 3H2 → CH4 + H2O. The specific catalytic activity of a supported metal catalyst increases with an increase in the number of active sites per mass of catalyst, which can be accomplished by increasing the metal content and/or decreasing the particle size of the metal. However, this leads to sintering of metal particles during the reaction, especially in highly exothermic reactions such as CO methanation. In this study, we prepared different SiO2-supported Ni catalysts by wet impregnation and sol–gel methods, and applied them to CO methanation. The prepared catalysts were characterized with N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Some problems associated with the wet impregnation method, such as sintering of Ni and the inability to load the silica with large amounts of Ni, were avoided by using the sol–gel method, in which size-controlled NiO was first synthesized using a polymer stabilizing agent, and then coated with a mesoporous silica shell through a polymerization approach. The prepared 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst exhibited the co-presence of Ni nanoparticles (mean size=8.0±4.4nm) and nanorods (mean length=15.5±13nm, mean width=8.1±4.4nm). This catalyst was far superior for CO methanation than the conventional 33wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst prepared by wet impregnation, in which the Ni particle size was 24.5nm. The 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst also exhibited excellent catalytic performance for selective CO methanation in the presence of an excessive amount of CO2. Keywords Silica-coated Ni Ni@SiO2 Sol–gel synthesis Sintering CO methanation 1 Introduction Supported metal catalysts are one of the main categories of heterogeneous catalysts [1]. Generally, they are composed of metal as an active site, and a support that provides mechanical strength and allows a high dispersion of metal. Since specific catalytic activity is proportional to the number of an active sites per mass of catalyst, various techniques have been employed to increase the number of active sites in the supported metal catalyst through increasing metal content and/or decreasing the particle size of the metal. Increasing metal content in a supported metal catalyst is a particularly convenient way to increase the specific activity, as long as the small metal particles can be preserved. However, supported metal catalysts with high metal contents often exhibit agglomeration of metal particles during the preparation step. Furthermore, sintering is a serious problem in highly exothermic reactions where the surface metal density is high. Therefore, a new preparation method is required to guarantee high specific activity of the catalyst while preventing agglomeration and sintering of metal particles. CO methanation is an important reaction for the production of synthetic natural gas from syngas (a mixture of CO and H2), as follows: CO+3H2 ↔CH4 +H2O; ΔH 298K =−206kJmol−1 It is also widely used in the purification process in hydrogen and ammonia production plants [2]. Recently, much attention has been paid to selective CO methanation in the presence of an excessive amount of CO2 to remove residual CO from the reformed gas used in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells [3]. Since it does not require an additional O2 supply (unlike the preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) process, a competing alternative to methanation for CO removal), a highly compact fuel processor design can be achieved, as long as catalytic activity comparable to the CO-PROX catalysts can be achieved with the CO methanation catalyst. Ni-based catalysts have been most commonly reported for this reaction [3]. Since their catalytic activities are lower than the noble metal catalysts used for CO-PROX, a novel approach is needed to increase the specific catalytic activity of the Ni-based catalysts. Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by conventional impregnation or ion exchange methods have been reported to have low surface areas [4]. Furthermore, these methods cause serious problems associated with poor Ni dispersion, which can result in reduced catalytic activity due to the fine Ni particles aggregating during the calcination and further reduction steps in catalyst preparation at high Ni loadings [4]. The excellent chemical resistance, thermal stability, controllable size/porosity, and good transparency of silica nanoparticles can be exploited to prepare silica-coated metal nanoparticles (M@SiO2) [5–23]. Sol–gel synthesis is a widely used “bottom-up” synthesis method for nano-sized materials. Ni@SiO2 core–shell catalysts can exhibit better catalytic properties compared with Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by conventional impregnation. Catalysts prepared through a sol–gel route have been reported to exhibit good catalytic performance for various reactions, such as steam reforming of ethanol [4] and methane [24–26], CO2 reforming of methane [24], partial oxidation of methane to syngas [27], and catalytic hydrogen transfer reactions [28]. Trimethylethoxysilane (TMOS) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) have been used as silicon precursors for synthesizing nano-silica. Liu et al. [29] summarized the different approaches used to prepare silica-coated metal nanoparticles. The commercially available amphiphilic polymer polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) is considered to be an efficient material for the protection and surface covering of metal nanoparticles by polymer strategies [30]. The main advantages associated with M@SiO2 materials include lower carbon deposition/carbon removal [31], a more reliable activity-size relationship, and improved catalytic activity [32–34]. The present study deals with the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic application of Ni@SiO2 core–shell catalysts for CO methanation. In the first step of catalyst preparation, size-controlled synthesis of NiO is performed using a polymer stabilizing agent, which is subsequently removed by calcination. The obtained NiO is coated with a mesoporous silica shell through a polymer approach using PVP as a polymeric pore generator. PVP is removed during calcination, yielding NiO nanoparticles coated with a mesoporous silica shell. This NiO@SiO2 can be reduced with H2 at 600°C to the Ni@SiO2 core–shell catalyst, which has a much larger number of smaller Ni nanoparticles than that obtained for Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by conventional impregnation methods. The former catalyst also shows a far higher catalytic activity for CO methanation than the latter catalysts, and exhibits excellent performance in selective CO methanation in the presence of CO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts In a typical synthesis of NiO nanoparticles, 3.0g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Junsei Chemical) was dissolved in 40mL of deionized water. Separately, 330mg of poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly (propylene)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG-PPG-PEG, M n =8,400, Aldrich) was dissolved in 100mL of water to which was added 1.0g of NaOH (Samchun Chemical). The prepared Ni precursor solution was added dropwise to the PEG-PPG-PEG mixture. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1h, centrifuged, washed three times with water and then with isopropanol (Aldrich), and dried at 50°C for 12h. The dried powder was calcined at 350°C for 2h in an air stream at a flow rate of 100mL/min. To prepare the NiO@SiO2 samples, 0.4g of finely powdered NiO nanoparticles was added to a PVP (M w =40,000, Aldrich) solution, which was prepared by dissolving 2.0g of PVP in 200mL of isopropanol. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12h. Then, 10mL of 25% aqueous NH3 solution (Aldrich) was added, followed by sonication for 30min. A silica precursor solution, which was prepared by dissolving 1g of TEOS (Aldrich) into 50mL of isopropanol was added dropwise to the slurry. After the resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24h, the slurry was centrifuged, washed twice with water and once with pure ethanol, dried at 80°C for 6h in an oven, and finally calcined in an air stream at 350°C for 24h. During the calcination process, PVP was removed, resulting in porous silica-coated NiO nanoparticles. This NiO@SiO2 sample was further reduced in a H2 stream at 600°C for 1h to form the Ni@SiO2 catalyst. Scheme 1 illustrates this method. For comparison, various Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni contents were prepared by wet impregnation. Several 50mL aqueous Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solutions with different concentrations were prepared and mixed with 5g of SiO2 (Zeochem, ZEOprep 60, S BET =542m2/g). The excess water was slowly removed using a rotary evaporator (BUCHI, Switzerland). The recovered powder was dried in an oven at 120°C for 12h and calcined in an air stream at 500°C for 3h. In some cases, this impregnation step was repeated several times to prepare Ni/SiO2 catalysts with higher Ni contents. These calcined samples were reduced in a H2 stream at 500°C for 1h before reaction. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The specific surface areas of the samples were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system and calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Prior to measurement, the samples were degassed under vacuum for 6h at 200°C. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried out on a Rigaku D/Max instrument with a Cu Kα source. The primary crystallite sizes of the catalysts were determined using the Scherrer equation [35], (1) L = 0.9 λ k α 1 B ( 2 θ ) cos θ max , where L denotes the average particle size, 0.9 is the value in radians when B (2θ) is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the peak, λ Kα1 is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation (0.15406nm), and θ max is the angular position at the (111) peak maximum of NiO or Ni. The Ni contents of the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Thermo Scientific iCAP 6500). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the sample was carried out on a Micromeritics Autochem 2910 in a conventional flow system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. H2-TPR was performed using 10mol% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 30mL/min in the temperature range of 313K to 1173K at a heating rate of 10°C/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G2 TEM (FEI) operated at 200kV, and were used to determine the Ni particle size. The samples were finely ground in a mortar and dispersed ultrasonically in ethanol. They were then deposited on a Cu grid covered by a perforated carbon film. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The activity tests were conducted at normal atmospheric pressure using a continuous fixed bed reactor system. Generally, 0.10g of the catalyst that had been retained between 45 and 80mesh sieves was loaded into the quartz reactor (internal diameter=3mm and length=345mm) and brought into contact with a feed composed of 1mol% CO, 50mol% H2, and 49mol% He at a flow rate of 100mL/min. The mass flow rate of each gas was controlled with a mass flow controller (MFC) (Brooks Instrument). The reaction temperature was measured by a thermocouple placed in the catalyst bed. In the selective CO methanation reaction, 0.10g of the catalyst was loaded into the quartz reactor and brought into contact with the feed composed of 0.3mol% CO, 20mol% CO2, 10mol% H2O, 50mol% H2, and 19.7 mol% He at a flow rate of 100mL/min. Liquid water was fed into the reactor by means of a syringe pump (KD Scientific Inc.). An evaporator was installed before the reactor and all the lines were warmed to avoid the condensation of water. The reactants and products were separated using a packed column filled with Carbosphere® and capillary Poraplot Q column, and analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (HP 6890) fitted with a thermal conductivity detector and flame ionization detector. The conversion of CO and CO2 and carbon yields to CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 were calculated using the following equations: (2) Co conversion (%)= ( [CO] i n − [ [CO] o u t ] ) [CO] i n × 100 , (3) C O 2 conversion (%)= ( [ C O 2 ] i n ) − [ C O 2 ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n × 100 , (4) Carbon yeild to C H 4 ( % ) = [ C H 4 ] o u t [ C H 4 ] i n × 100 , (5) Carbon yeild to C 2 H 6 ( % ) = ( 2 × [ C 2 H 6 ] o u t ) [ C O ] i n × 100 , (6) Carbon yield to C 3 H 8 ( % ) = ( 3 × [ C 3 H 8 ] o u t ) [ C O ] i n × 100 , where [CO]in and [CO2]in represent the concentration of CO and CO2 in the feed stream and [CO]out, [CO2]out, [CH4]out, [C2H6]out, and [C3H8]out denote the concentration of CO, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 in the output stream, respectively. A moisture trap was installed ahead of the gas chromatograph to remove the moisture formed during the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 N2 physisorption The physical properties of the catalysts were measured using N2 physisorption, as presented in Table 1 . For Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the wet impregnation method, the BET surface area and pore volume decrease with increasing Ni content. This is quite reasonable as BET surface and pore volume are specific values, and are mainly dependent on the mass fraction of SiO2. Conversely, there is no noticeable change in the average pore diameter among Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni contents. The constant average pore diameter for all the catalysts reveals that all the Ni precursors were evenly introduced to the interior pore walls of the support without causing pore plugging, even though the Ni content ranged from 7 to 33wt%. As shown in Fig. S1, the presence of mesopores in the silica shells is confirmed in the case of Ni@SiO2. The pore sizes range from 2 to 10nm, peaking at 6.5nm. It has been previously reported that mesopores with pore sizes of 3–4nm are generated due to the templating effect of PVP [36]. 3.1.2 XRD In order to investigate the bulk crystalline structure of the Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni contents after reduction, their XRD patterns were obtained. As shown in Fig. 1 , only metallic Ni is observed as the Ni species in all samples. The XRD peak representing Ni is strengthened with increasing Ni content. The crystallite sizes of the Ni were calculated using the Scherrer equation, and are listed in Table 1. There is no noticeable change in the crystallite size of Ni in the Ni/SiO2 catalysts when increasing the Ni content from 7 to 13wt%. However, the crystallite size of Ni increases from 12.3 to 24.5nm with increasing Ni content from 13 to 33wt%. The XRD patterns of unsupported NiO and NiO@SiO2 were also obtained. Pure NiO nanorods exhibit the fcc-NiO phase (JCPDS No. 78-0429) with typical reflections for the (111), (200), and (220) planes at 2θ =37°, 43° and 64°, respectively (Fig. 1(e)). These XRD peaks are not altered in the NiO@SiO2 patterns, even after encapsulation by a silica layer (Fig. 1(f)). The characteristic silica peak (2θ =22.5°) is not observed for NiO@SiO2. The crystallite size of NiO in unsupported NiO is 5.7nm, and this crystallite size was confirmed to be preserved in NiO@SiO2. After reduction at 600°C, all the XRD peaks representing NiO disappear for unsupported Ni and the Ni@SiO2 catalyst. Instead, the XRD pattern for Ni (JCPDS No. 04-0850) is observed, with reflections for the (111), (200), and (220) planes appearing at 2θ =44°, 52°, and 76°, respectively. Therefore, metallic Ni is the only Ni phase present in these catalysts after reduction. However, there is a significant difference in the peak intensity between them. The XRD peaks representing Ni are significantly more intensified for the unsupported Ni catalyst than for the Ni@SiO2 catalyst. This implies that the crystallite size of Ni in the former catalyst is much larger than in the latter. The crystallite sizes of Ni in unsupported Ni and Ni@SiO2 are 43 and 13nm, respectively. The crystallite size of Ni in the unsupported Ni catalyst reduced at 300°C is 29nm, which is much smaller than that of the unsupported Ni catalyst reduced at 600°C. It is noteworthy that the 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst maintains a small Ni particle size, despite its high Ni content and high-temperature reduction pretreatment. 3.1.3 H2-TPR Fig. 2 exhibits the H2-TPR profiles of NiO@SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 samples calcined at 500°C. The TPR peaks of Ni/SiO2 samples with different Ni loadings show that peak intensity increases with Ni loading. The TPR profile of NiO@SiO2 differs significantly from that of 33wt% Ni/SiO2. The TPR peak intensity is higher and the peak position is shifted to a higher temperature. The enhanced TPR peak intensity of NiO@SiO2 is due to its larger Ni content than that of 33wt% Ni/SiO2. The broadening of the main TPR peak is attributed to the presence of different sizes of NiO particles, and the interaction of NiO and silica. It is generally accepted that smaller NiO particles can be more easily reduced than larger ones, and that a strong interaction between NiO and a support can cause a shift of the TPR peak to a higher temperature. Sometimes, smaller metal oxide nanoparticles and a support can strongly interact, which makes it difficult to interpret the TPR data considering particle size of the metal oxide alone. The shifting of the TPR peak to a higher temperature for NiO@SiO2 compared with that of Ni/SiO2 can be ascribed to the difficulty in reducing NiO when it is encapsulated in a silica shell [34,37]. The interfacial area between NiO and silica can be larger for NiO@SiO2 compared with that of Ni/SiO2, which might cause the TPR peak shift. It is noteworthy that the main TPR peak of NiO@SiO2 includes a low-temperature shoulder peak centered at 342°C. This implies the co-presence of both small and large nickel oxide particles encapsulated within the silica shell, which is supported by the TEM analysis (but not by XRD). 3.1.4 (HR)TEM The TEM image of an as-prepared NiO sample shows the presence of NiO nanorods (Fig. S2). Analysis of randomly distributed nanorods reveals that their average length and width is 9.8±5.1 and 4.3±0.9nm, respectively (Fig. S2). Only rods and elliptical particles are observed in the TEM images. Typically, NiO nanoparticles are present in the form of nanorods with an aspect ratio of 2.3. The presence of clusters comprising several nanorods, as well as isolated rods, is confirmed. The HRTEM image of the NiO sample reveals an interplanar distance of 0.24nm corresponding to the (111) planes in NiO (Fig. 3(A)) [38,39]. The TEM image of the as-prepared NiO@SiO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 3(C). Uncoated NiO particles are not observed, which suggests that the coating process adopted is effective. As shown in Fig. 3(C), the silica particles are not well separated and have grown together, forming aggregates of silica particles with encapsulated nickel particles. This is consistent with the results of Li et al. [34] who prepared NiO@SiO2 samples with BET surface areas in the range 63–117m2/g. Our NiO@SiO2 sample has a BET surface area of 122m2/g. Analysis of randomly distributed core–shell structures shows that the thickness of the silica shell is 6±2.5nm. Fig. 3 (B) shows an HRTEM image of the Ni@SiO2 catalyst. The presence of porous silica encapsulating Ni nanoparticles can be confirmed. The porous structure of the catalyst is confirmed to be highly stable, even to reduction at 600°C. Fig. S3 shows a TEM image of the Ni@SiO2 catalyst after a reduction at 600°C. No Ni particles without a silica coating can be observed. As shown in Fig. S3, not every Ni nanoparticle was coated separately with silica because of the presence of several NiO rods within a silica shell. Compared with the size of the NiO nanoparticles, the length and width of the Ni nanoparticles increases after reduction at 600°C. The length of pure NiO nanorods ranges from 6 to 15nm, while it increases to 11–25nm in the Ni@SiO2 samples (Fig. S3). This increase in length of the Ni rods can be attributed to both the high-temperature reductive pretreatment and the presence of several NiO rods within a single silica shell. Fig. 3(D) reveals that the catalyst contains both well-separated silica-coated Ni rods/particles (black arrows) and multiple particles (white arrows). 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic performances of Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation with different Ni contents in CO methanation are presented in Fig. 4 . The catalytic activity increases with increasing Ni content. The 7wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibits the highest T 50 (the temperature at which 50% CO conversion is achieved), while the T 50 significantly decreases with an increase in Ni loading from 7 to 13wt%, as shown in Table 1. Further increase in Ni content does not lead to a significant decrease in T 50. When the Ni content is increased from 24 to 33wt%, only a slight decrease in the value of T 50 is observed (from 221 to 216°C). This illustrates how the improvement of catalytic activity achievable by increasing Ni content is limited when using conventional wet impregnation methodology. For all reaction temperatures, CH4 is the major product and very small amount of C2H6 was measured as an additional hydrocarbon product. Comparison of the temperature at which 100% CO conversion occurs (T 100) reveals that all the catalysts have the same T 100, except for the 7wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst. As shown in Table 1, there is no noticeable change in the crystallite size of Ni in the Ni/SiO2 catalysts when increasing Ni content from 7 to 13wt%. This implies that the number of active sites can be increased proportionally with increasing Ni content for these samples. This explains the significant drop in T 50 and T 100 for the Ni/SiO2 catalysts when the Ni content is increased from 7 to 13wt%. However, the crystallite size of Ni increases from 12.3 to 24.5nm with increasing Ni content from 13 to 33wt%. This increase in the crystallite size of Ni explains the slight change in T 50 and T 100 for Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni contents. The effect of the increase in the number of active site with increasing Ni content is countervailed by the effect of the accompanying increase in the crystallite size of the Ni. The surface area of Ni for each Ni/SiO2 catalyst can be calculated based on the assumption that Ni nanoparticles have a hemispherical shape. The Ni surface areas of 7wt% Ni/SiO2, 13wt% Ni/SiO2, 24wt% Ni/SiO2, and 33wt% Ni/SiO2 were estimated to be 3.8, 7.1, 10, and 9.1m2/gcat., respectively. This also suggests that the catalytic activity is closely related the Ni surface area, and that high loading does not guarantee a higher catalytic activity than the Ni/SiO2 catalyst prepared by conventional impregnation. To increase the Ni content while preserving the small crystallite size of Ni, Ni@SiO2 catalysts were prepared and applied to CO methanation. In order to investigate the effect of the silica layer on catalytic activity, unsupported Ni catalysts prepared through reductive treatment with H2 at 300 and 600°C were also prepared for comparison. Fig. 5 shows that 100% CO conversion is achieved at 219°C over the 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst, while the unsupported Ni catalyst reduced at 600°C shows negligible catalytic activity at all tested temperatures. The catalytic activity for the unsupported Ni catalysts can be increased by lowering the reduction temperature from 600 to 300°C. The unsupported Ni catalyst reduced at 300°C exhibits a maximum CO conversion of 72% at 318°C. For all reaction temperatures, CH4 is the major product and very small amounts of C2H6 and C3H8 were measured only over Ni@SiO2 catalyst as additional hydrocarbon products. The crystallite size of Ni in the unsupported Ni catalyst reduced at 300°C is 29nm, which is much smaller than that of the unsupported Ni catalyst reduced at 600°C. This explains the higher catalytic activity of the former catalyst, and clearly demonstrates the key role of small Ni particles and the effectiveness of silica-coated Ni catalysts. 55wt% Ni@SiO2 is confirmed to have a superior catalytic activity to 33wt% Ni/SiO2 at all reaction temperatures under the same reaction conditions (Fig. S4). In order to compare the catalytic activity and stability of 55wt% Ni@SiO2 and 33wt% Ni/SiO2, the specific CH4 formation rate based on the mass of the catalyst and the normalized CH4 formation rate based on the Ni content were obtained over both catalysts at the same reaction temperature (Fig. S5). In any case, 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst showed a much higher reaction rate than 33wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst. Both catalysts appeared to be stable during the stability test for 20h. Owing to the excellent catalytic performance of 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst in CO methanation, it was applied to selective CO methanation in the presence of CO2 and H2O (Fig. 6 ). CO conversion increases with increasing temperature, reaching its maximum value at 210°C, and then decreases with a further increase in the temperature above 230°C. The fact that CO conversion decreases with increasing temperatures above 230°C can be explained by the reverse water-gas shift reaction (CO2 +H2 ↔CO+H2O), which was confirmed to proceed over Ni@SiO2 catalyst with CO2 methanation at the same time (Fig. S6). The exit CH4 concentration was higher than the CO concentration in the input stream at high temperatures, which implies that CO2 is also transformed into CH4. However, the exit CH4 concentration is less than 2% even at 240°C and CO2 conversion does not occur significantly until 240°C, which is a very important requirement for selective CO methanation catalysts used in fuel processing. In this experiment, only CH4 is detected as a formed hydrocarbon. Therefore, the 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst prepared in this study is not only highly active for CO methanation, but is also selective for CO methanation in the presence of CO2. Several works that concern the synthesis of Ni@SiO2 for catalytic applications have been reported. Lucchini et al. [15] developed a method for the continuous synthesis of Ni nanoparticles using a segmented flow tubular reactor, the particles then being coated in porous silica via a sol–gel route using cetyltrimethylammonium bromide, ammonium nitrate, and TEOS. Their Ni@SiO2 comprised a Ni core of ca. 170nm protected by a 30–40nm microporous SiO2 layer [15]. Miyao et al. [22] prepared mesoporous silica-coated Ni/AlVOx by the hydrolysis of TEOS and titanium isopropoxide in a suspension formed using Ni/AlVOx powder and an ethanol–water solution of hexadecyl-trimethylammonium bromide. The average thickness of the layer was 15nm and the average diameter of the pores was 3.3nm for the as-prepared sample [22]. Hayashi et al. [23] also prepared a core–shell structure composed of vanadium oxide and Ni particles covered by mesoporous silica, but the crystallite size of Ni was 78nm when the core material consisted of Ni alone. Li et al. [34] prepared a Ni@SiO2 sample and reported that the particle size of Ni increased from 6.3±2.1 to 7.9±2.4nm after use in the partial oxidation of methane at 700°C. Thus, compared with previous works, this study reports comparable or improved results in terms of the resistance to sintering of the Ni nanoparticles, coverage of the silica shell, degree of nickel loading, and ease of preparation. Interestingly, even after reduction at 600°C and use in highly exothermic reactions, the majority of the Ni nanoparticles are preserved. This is due to the presence of the silica shell, which successfully prevents agglomeration, resulting in a high catalytic activity. The presence of well-separated small Ni particles stabilized by the silica shell is also confirmed by HRTEM images of the Ni@SiO2 catalyst after reaction (Fig. 7 ). 4 Conclusion Silica-supported Ni catalysts (Ni/SiO2) were prepared by a conventional wet impregnation method, and a silica-coated Ni catalyst (Ni@SiO2) was prepared by a sol–gel technique. The Ni@SiO2 catalyst exhibited co-presence of Ni particles (mean size=8.0±4.4nm) and nanorods (mean length=15.5±13nm, mean width=8.1±4.4nm). Conversely, the 33wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibited the presence of Ni particles with a mean size of 24.5nm. In Ni@SiO2, the Ni nanoparticles were prevented from sintering, while severe sintering was observed in the unsupported Ni nanoparticles and Ni/SiO2 catalysts after reduction at high temperature. Owing to the stabilized smaller Ni nanoparticles, Ni@SiO2 exhibited superior catalytic activity for CO methanation than the Ni/SiO2 catalysts. The Ni@SiO2 catalyst also exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the selective methanation of CO in the presence of excess CO2. coredata.dc:description: The specific catalytic activity of a supported metal catalyst increases with an increase in the number of active sites per mass of catalyst, which can be accomplished by increasing the metal content and/or decreasing the particle size of the metal. However, this leads to sintering of metal particles during the reaction, especially in highly exothermic reactions such as CO methanation. In this study, we prepared different SiO2-supported Ni catalysts by wet impregnation and sol–gel methods, and applied them to CO methanation. The prepared catalysts were characterized with N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Some problems associated with the wet impregnation method, such as sintering of Ni and the inability to load the silica with large amounts of Ni, were avoided by using the sol–gel method, in which size-controlled NiO was first synthesized using a polymer stabilizing agent, and then coated with a mesoporous silica shell through a polymerization approach. The prepared 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst exhibited the co-presence of Ni nanoparticles (mean size=8.0±4.4nm) and nanorods (mean length=15.5±13nm, mean width=8.1±4.4nm). This catalyst was far superior for CO methanation than the conventional 33wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst prepared by wet impregnation, in which the Ni particle size was 24.5nm. The 55wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst also exhibited excellent catalytic performance for selective CO methanation in the presence of an excessive amount of CO2.
coredata.dc:title: A highly loaded Ni@SiO2 core–shell catalyst for CO methanation
